SD endorses the provisions allowing choice of applicable property law, recognizing this autonomy as vital for cross-border couples facing complex legal environments.  
SD commends the issue’s focus on reducing bureaucratic burdens through unified recognition mechanisms, aligning with their manifesto priorities for EU citizen mobility.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the compatibility of the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0126) with the principle of subsidiarity, as highlighted by the Italian Senate’s reasoned opinion. It approved the Commission’s proposal as amended, emphasizing alignment with Article 81(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which governs judicial cooperation in civil matters. Parliament urged the Commission to revise its proposal under Article 293(2) to reflect these amendments and called on the Council to either notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text or reconsult Parliament if intending to substantially alter the proposal. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural accountability while prioritizing substantive legal coherence and interinstitutional dialogue.

title: Information and consultation of workers, anticipation and management of restructuring: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on information and consultation of workers, anticipation and management of restructuring
background: Economic crises, globalization, and industrial shifts have driven frequent corporate restructuring in the EU, raising concerns over worker rights, social impacts, and compliance with existing labor directives. The Parliament will discuss improving frameworks for worker consultation, anticipation of restructuring processes, and mitigating socioeconomic effects of industrial change across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on anticipatory restructuring strategies and worker retraining, aligning perfectly with their commitment to balancing economic competitiveness with social protections.  
EPP applauds the integration of EU structural funds for green and digital sector upskilling, advancing their priority of future-oriented labor market policies.  
EPP endorses mandatory multi-stakeholder dialogues and protections for dependent SMEs as critical to responsible corporate governance frameworks.  
EPP proposes enhancing the accessibility of training programs for disabled workers by specifying accommodation requirements in ESF-funded initiatives.  
EPP suggests reinforcing subsidiarity by allowing member states to build upon existing national restructuring models rather than imposing rigid EU-wide procedural mandates.

EFD rejects the issue’s failure to extend European Globalisation Adjustment Fund coverage to small businesses and self-employed workers, directly contradicting Article 225 TFEU’s social solidarity principles.  
EFD opposes the issue’s implicit alignment with austerity-driven "budget consolidation," which EFD views as incompatible with crisis mitigation for vulnerable entrepreneurs.  
EFD fully doubts with the proposal’s reliance on existing EU funds, demanding explicit amendments to Article 4 to include SME-specific retraining subsidies.  
The issue overlooks EFD’s emphasis on individual entrepreneurship as a crisis survival mechanism, requiring new clauses to allocate ESF resources for microenterprise grants.  
EFD highlights the framework’s inconsistency with labor realities in member states like Poland, where two-thirds of SMEs lack access to restructuring safeguards under current EGF rules.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue's mandate for EU-wide minimum standards on worker consultation, aligning perfectly with their commitment to social justice in green economic transitions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Article 4 to explicitly require binding retraining plans before restructuring approval, ensuring workers are never treated as disposable assets.  
GREEN_EFA applauds linking EU funding to compliance with worker protections, effectively advancing their manifesto goals for accountable corporate conduct.  
GREEN_EFA urges faster implementation of psychosocial support clauses, noting current disparities in member states’ crisis responses undermine trust in restructuring processes.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the issue’s anti-discrimination safeguards must explicitly prohibit age-based layoffs in digital transitions, as highlighted in recent EGF cases.

ALDE conditionally agrees early worker consultation provisions but opposes mandatory EU-wide retraining funds, advocating voluntary employer-led initiatives to avoid financial strain.  
ALDE rejects binding restructuring directives as fully disputeing with subsidiarity, insisting measures remain non-binding guidelines to preserve national flexibility.  
ALDE requests deletion of redundancy "last resort" requirements (Art. 6), arguing market adaptability necessitates unrestricted corporate decision-making during crises.  
ALDE opposes standardized annual training hours, urging replacement with sector-specific collective bargaining to reflect diverse business realities.  
ALDE fundamentally objects to EU penalties for non-compliance (Resolution §18), asserting enforcement must remain strictly under member state competence.

SD completely advocates the issue’s call for binding EU legislation to enforce early worker consultation, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to transforming restructuring into a socially responsible process.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to prioritize retraining and internal mobility over redundancies, advancing SD’s vision of worker-centric economic adaptation.  
SD completely advocates leveraging EU funds like ESF and EGF for regional reconversion, reflecting SD’s longstanding advocacy for robust social safety nets during industrial transitions.  
SD perfectly aligns with mandating cross-border union consultations during restructurings, reinforcing SD’s principle of transnational solidarity in labor rights.  
SD completely advocates penalizing non-compliant companies through funding restrictions, a measure that directly advances SD’s agenda of corporate accountability.

ECR rejects fundamentally the imposition of EU-level regulatory frameworks for worker consultation, viewing this as an infringement on national sovereignty and corporate autonomy.  
ECR opposes the issue’s emphasis on prolonged stakeholder dialogues, arguing that restructuring requires swift execution without bureaucratic delays to maintain competitiveness.  
ECR contends that mandated training programs and EU funding penalties contradict principles of subsidiarity, advocating instead for voluntary employer-led initiatives.  
ECR asserts that binding consultation rules undermine managerial prerogative, creating legal vulnerabilities that could paralyze necessary restructuring processes.  
ECR rejects the issue’s presumption that EU oversight improves outcomes, insisting proven national labor market mechanisms better balance worker protections with economic realities.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on non-binding language ("should", "could") as fundamentally inadequate to enforce worker protections against profit-driven restructuring.  
GUE_NGL opposes the prioritization of corporate freedom over worker interests, which contradicts their principle that economic decisions must prioritize public welfare over private profits.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to mandate worker co-determination in restructuring processes, leaving critical decisions under unilateral corporate control.  
GUE_NGL denounces the implicit acceptance of layoffs as an economic inevitability, highlighting that dismissals result from political choices favoring austerity rather than necessity.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to socialize restructuring costs equitably, noting it perpetuates a system where workers bear crises caused by corporate mismanagement and EU austerity policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a comprehensive EU legal framework to enhance worker consultation, anticipate restructuring, and manage its social and economic impacts responsibly. It urged the Commission to propose legislation under Article 225 TFEU, emphasizing cooperation among companies, workers’ representatives, and public authorities to balance competitiveness with worker protections. Key recommendations included integrating restructuring into long-term corporate strategies, prioritizing human resource development, and ensuring redundancies are a last resort after exploring alternatives like retraining, redeployment, and internal mobility. The resolution stressed early information-sharing with stakeholders, including dependent SMEs, and mandated training programs (with annual hours set by law or collective agreements) to boost employability, particularly in green and digital sectors. It advocated for EU funds (ERDF, ESF, EGF) to support retraining and regional reconversion, while penalizing non-compliant companies by withholding EU/national funding for five years. Anti-discrimination safeguards, especially against age bias, and psychosocial support for affected workers were highlighted. Public authorities were tasked with facilitating multi-stakeholder dialogues, skill assessments, and industrial site rehabilitation. The framework aimed to align with the EU 2020 strategy, promoting sustainable growth without financial burdens on the EU budget.

title: Mutual recognition of protection measures in civil matters: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on mutual recognition of protection measures in civil matters
background: The EU’s existing framework for judicial cooperation in civil matters, including mutual recognition of judgments, and the 2011 Commission proposal aimed at addressing cross-border protection gaps for crime victims, established the context. The Parliament will discuss a regulation on mutual recognition of civil protection measures to enhance legal safeguards across member states.

EPP fundamentally supports the regulation as it perfectly aligns with the party's foundational commitment to cross-border judicial cooperation and protection of vulnerable citizens exercising free movement rights.  
EPP emphasizes that the mutual recognition mechanism effectively advances their priority of creating a seamless European justice area where victims maintain protection across all Member States without administrative barriers.  
EPP highlights the issue’s gender-sensitive approach as fully consistent with their manifesto pledges to combat domestic violence and uphold children’s rights through harmonized civil law instruments.  
EPP applauds the integration of multilingual certificates and simplified procedures as exemplary implementations of their "justice without borders" principle outlined in the Stockholm Programme.  
EPP underscores that the regulation’s coherence with the Brussels IIa Regulation and preventive focus on repeat offenses exemplifies their vision for a victim-centered EU legal architecture.

EFD partially agrees the cross-border recognition framework but requests revisions to Article 3 regarding enforcement mechanisms to prevent overreach into national civil procedures.  
EFD emphasizes that harmonized jurisdiction rules must explicitly exempt member states with established domestic violence protection systems under Protocol No 36.  
EFD warns the issue's mandatory mediation provisions conflict with their stance against EU-imposed alternative dispute issue models in family law matters.  
EFD demands amendment of Clause 12 to require dual criminality checks for protection measures involving restraining orders to align with subsidiarity principles.  
 While supporting mobility goals, EFD contends the regulation's Article 7(2) fails to address risks of forum shopping in parental responsibility cases.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the establishment of cross-border recognition mechanisms for civil protection measures, aligning perfectly with their commitment to combat gender-based violence and safeguard vulnerable groups.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on preventing domestic abuse and stalking, which directly advances their priority of ensuring psychological and physical security for women and children.  
GREEN_EFA approves the harmonized enforcement of prohibitions on perpetrators, such as restricted access to victims’ spaces, as critical to systemic protection across Member States.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing implementation timelines to include mandatory progress reviews, ensuring Member States expedite adoption without opposing the regulation’s core principles.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s coherence with gender equality frameworks, urging integration of trauma-informed legal support to further strengthen victim protections.

ALDE firmly supports the issue as it perfectly aligns with our commitment to safeguarding free movement and protecting vulnerable individuals from gender-based violence across all member states.  
ALDE celebrates the regulation’s harmonized framework for mutual recognition of protection orders, which effectively advances our priority of ensuring victims’ rights transcend national borders without bureaucratic barriers.  
ALDE emphasizes that this issue embodies our longstanding principles of gender equality and judicial cooperation, creating a tangible European safety net for women and children fleeing domestic abuse.  
ALDE applauds the integration of victim protections with EU citizenship rights, reinforcing our vision of a Union where security and freedom are inseparable pillars of justice.  
ALDE recognizes the historic significance of this measure in fulfilling the promise of European integration, ensuring no citizen is deprived of safety due to jurisdictional fragmentation.

SD strongly upholds the mutual recognition of civil protection measures as essential for safeguarding free movement rights, aligning with SD's commitment to victim-centered justice systems.  
SD approves the harmonization of civil and criminal protection instruments, enhancing cross-border legal certainty for gender violence survivors.  
SD endorses the standardized multilingual certificate as a critical simplification measure that reduces administrative burdens on vulnerable individuals.  
SD applauds the issue's focus on automatic recognition of protection orders across member states, effectively advancing SD's priority of eliminating jurisdictional gaps in domestic violence cases.  
SD proposes urging member states to expedite ratification of the Istanbul Convention to further strengthen the regulatory framework's preventive dimensions.

ECR completely againsts the extension of mutual recognition principles to civil law measures, asserting this creates jurisdictional conflicts with national legal systems.  
ECR rejects EU competence in harmonizing civil protection orders, citing incompatibility with common law traditions and subsidiarity principles.  
ECR argues the proposal overlooks critical disparities between criminal and civil law frameworks, risking legal uncertainty for victims.  
ECR maintains that civil law protections lack sufficient statutory definition across member states, undermining mutual trust requirements.  
ECR abstains due to unresolved tensions between the regulation’s objectives and preservation of national civil justice autonomy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0276) concerning judicial cooperation in civil matters, emphasizing the need to strengthen legal frameworks for cross-border family law disputes and enhance protections for vulnerable groups, particularly women and children. The resolution, grounded in Treaty provisions (Article 81(2)(a), (e), and (f) TFEU), focused on improving access to justice, ensuring equitable recognition of civil judgments across member states, and addressing gender-based disparities in legal proceedings. It advocated for harmonized rules on jurisdiction, applicable law, and enforcement of decisions in matrimonial matters, parental responsibility, and maintenance obligations, with specific attention to safeguarding children’s rights and victims of domestic violence. The Parliament underscored the importance of integrating gender equality principles into civil justice systems and called for measures to prevent discrimination. It also urged the Commission to ensure coherence with existing EU instruments, such as the Brussels IIa Regulation, and stressed the role of mediation and alternative dispute resolution. The resolution mandated forwarding Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, while retaining procedural safeguards to review any substantial amendments to the proposal.

title: Organised crime, corruption, and money laundering: REPORT on organised crime, corruption and money laundering: recommendations on action and initiatives to be taken (final report)
background: Escalating transnational organized crime, corruption, and money laundering activities across EU member states, compounded by fragmented legal frameworks and cross-border enforcement challenges, alongside estimated annual losses exceeding €120 billion from corruption, prompted calls for coordinated action. The Parliament will discuss strengthening EU-wide strategies and legal measures to combat financial crimes and criminal networks’ operational capabilities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the establishment of specialized national prosecution units for organized crime, aligning with the issue's call for enhanced judicial cooperation through Eurojust and joint investigation teams.  
EPP absolutely supports accelerated implementation of asset confiscation frameworks, directly advancing the mutual recognition of freezing orders under Framework Decision 2006/783/JHA as prioritized in the issue.  
EPP proposes expediting the phase-out of €500 banknotes through amendments to Regulation 1889/2005 cash controls, reinforcing anti-money laundering efforts while maintaining payment service integrity under Directive 2007/64/EC.  
EPP strongly approves expanding maritime cooperation against human trafficking networks, operationalizing the issue's emphasis on cross-border police collaboration through Europol and Frontex mechanisms.  
EPP urges immediate activation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office proposal, noting this perfectly aligns with their 2019-2024 priority to combat EU budget fraud through centralized investigative capacity.

EFD partially accepts the issue’s public procurement safeguards but demands amendments to Article 4 to permanently bar corruption-convicted entities from EU tenders.  
EFD insists the text must explicitly prohibit individuals convicted of financial crimes from holding public office, per Rolandas Paksas’ electoral integrity concerns.  
EFD requests revising Section III to abolish all banking secrecy regimes and tax havens within the EU, aligning with anti-money laundering frameworks.  
EFD highlights unresolved risks of political-mafia collusion in certain states, urging targeted sanctions mechanisms beyond COM(2012)0732’s scope.  
EFD proposes expanding cybercrime provisions to address counterfeit pharmaceutical trafficking and electoral infiltration by organized groups, per Fontana’s warnings.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue's holistic approach to combating financial crimes through enhanced judicial cooperation and tax haven elimination, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to systemic justice reforms and fundamental rights protection.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on closing banking secrecy loopholes and addressing corporate corruption cases like Libor, which directly advances their manifesto priorities for economic transparency and corporate accountability.  
GREEN_EFA proposes excluding mass surveillance tools like EU PNR/SWIFT programs from security measures, advocating instead for targeted investigations with democratic oversight to enhance privacy safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA urges accelerated adoption of common procedural standards across member states to strengthen Europol's effectiveness in fighting human trafficking, reflecting their cross-border solidarity principles.  
GREEN_EFA approves binding ethical rules for public officials and EU-wide lobby registers as critical steps to prevent political corruption, while calling for stricter enforcement of campaign finance limits.

ALDE strongly upholds the criminalization of mafia associations and asset confiscation measures, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to dismantle organized crime's financial infrastructure.  
ALDE approves enhanced cross-border investigations through Europol expansion, proposing increased staffing levels to match FBI-scale operational capacity as a strategic enhancement.  
ALDE endorses establishing a European Day of Remembrance for mafia victims, effectively advancing civic awareness priorities in the issue.  
ALDE advocates for mandatory container inspection quotas at EU entry points to operationalize the issue's border security objectives.  
ALDE emphasizes urgent implementation of tax transparency measures under COM(2012)0351, matching manifesto commitments to combat fiscal fraud.

SD strongly accepts the issue's call for harmonized anti-money laundering legislation and abolition of banking secrecy, aligning with SD's 2022 manifesto commitment to financial transparency.  
SD endorses the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office as critical for cross-border investigations, particularly noting the €25bn annual human trafficking profits requiring coordinated asset confiscation.  
SD proposes accelerating implementation timelines for the EU corruption assessment report, emphasizing its necessity to combat the estimated €100bn annual corruption costs across member states.  
SD approves the social reuse model for confiscated mafia assets, highlighting successful Italian precedents mentioned in debate as replicable best practices for community regeneration.  
SD emphasizes urgency in regulating tax havens through COM(2012)0102 revisions, particularly targeting offshore protections used by political elites as detailed in the Bulgarian representative's intervention.

ECR rejects the proposal for a European Public Prosecutor as firmly opposeing with their principle of national sovereignty in judicial matters.  
ECR opposes asset confiscation without final court verdicts, warning this enables political abuse in member states lacking robust rule of law safeguards.  
ECR totally disputes decriminalizing defamation, arguing it risks enabling unsubstantiated claims that damage private and commercial reputations.  
ECR objects to the issue's failure to mandate Schengen expansion freezes until candidate states prove effective anti-corruption frameworks.  
ECR criticizes the approach for prioritizing new EU institutions over strengthening cross-border police cooperation through existing mechanisms like Europol.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on financial deregulation frameworks that perpetuate capitalist structures enabling money laundering and tax evasion.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the omission of systemic critiques linking organized crime to privatization schemes and public asset stripping condemned in João Ferreira's intervention.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to mandate full abolition of banking secrecy regimes, contradicting Søren Bo Søndergaard's emphasis on exposing shadow economies through cash transaction bans.  
GUE_NGL disputes the push for a European Public Prosecutor's Office as undermining national judicial sovereignty, aligning with Cornelis de Jong's warnings about procedural rights overreach.  
GUE_NGL declares the report incompatible with its anti-capitalist platform by ignoring root causes like tax havens and speculative finance systems denounced across all interventions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about strengthening the EU’s legal and operational framework to combat corruption, money laundering, organized crime, and related financial crimes, emphasizing alignment with international standards such as the Council of Europe conventions, OECD anti-bribery measures, and FATF’s 40 recommendations and 9 special recommendations. It highlighted the need for enhanced cooperation through mechanisms like Eurojust, Europol, Asset Recovery Offices, and joint investigation teams, alongside mutual recognition of confiscation orders and freezing procedures under Framework Decisions 2003/577/JHA, 2005/212/JHA, and 2006/783/JHA. The resolution stressed the importance of regulating financial transactions, including cash controls under Regulation 1889/2005, payment services under Directive 2007/64/EC, and addressing shadow banking and tax evasion through initiatives like COM(2012)0102 and COM(2012)0351. It called for robust public procurement rules (Directives 2004/17/EC and 2004/18/EC) to prevent corruption, improved cybercrime prevention via the European Cybercrime Centre (COM(2012)0140), and better data collection through the Crime Statistics Action Plan 2011-2015 (COM(2011)0713). The Parliament also urged action against emerging threats like online gambling (COM(2012)0596) and sports-related corruption, while advocating for evaluations of existing frameworks, including the Prüm Decision (COM(2012)0732) and the EU Crime Prevention Network (COM(2012)0717), to ensure effectiveness and coherence in EU criminal policy.

title: Situation in the Central African Republic: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the situation in the Central African Republic
background: The Central African Republic faced prolonged instability since 1960, with recurring rebellions and governance challenges despite natural resource wealth. A December 2012 rebel offensive citing unmet peace terms exacerbated humanitarian crises and rights abuses, prompting regional mediation efforts. The Parliament will discuss the crisis’ security implications, human rights concerns, and stabilization initiatives.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's limited focus on immediate political agreements without addressing systemic corruption enabling resource exploitation, completely doubting with EPP's principle of transparent governance.  
EPP opposes the inadequate emphasis on countering China's non-democratic economic expansion in CAR, overlooking critical aspects of EU strategic influence outlined in Danuta Jazłowiecka's intervention.  
EPP condemns the issue's failure to mandate direct EU military stabilization support for regional actors like Cameroon, inconsistent with Bernd Posselt's call for holistic Sahel security frameworks.  
EPP disputes the humanitarian access provisions as insufficiently binding, echoing Krzysztof Lisek's demand for enforceable safe corridors rather than appeals to government cooperation.  
EPP challenges the issue's reliance on the Kimberley Process alone, which Sari Essayah's child soldier analysis shows ignores parallel trafficking networks fueling rebel groups.

SD rejects the issue's framework for failing to mandate immediate ICC prosecutions of child soldier recruiters, contradicting S&D's absolute stance on wartime accountability.  
SD opposes fundamentally the absence of binding EU sanctions against Kimberley Process violators, inconsistent with S&D's diamond trade transparency principles.  
This fundamentally rejects with SD's position that peace processes must prioritize victim compensation before rebel reintegration.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as concrete EU military support for ECCAS troops to protect humanitarian corridors.

GUE_NGL totally opposes the issue’s failure to explicitly integrate economic and social rights as human rights, particularly local populations’ sovereignty over natural resources.  
GUE_NGL rejects the superficial treatment of resource management, which prioritizes international regulatory compliance over community-led economic justice, contradicting their anti-imperialist principles.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as binding mechanisms to ensure diamond revenues directly uplift CAR’s impoverished communities, perpetuating extractive exploitation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s human rights framework for neglecting enforceable guarantees of equitable resource access, a core tenet of their anti-capitalist agenda.  
The issue’s emphasis on security-centric solutions conflicts with GUE_NGL’s demand for systemic poverty eradication through redistributive economic policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised grave concerns over the escalating crisis in the Central African Republic (CAR) following the Seleka rebel coalition’s December 2012 offensive, which endangered civilians, exacerbated instability, and violated human rights, including sexual violence, looting, and child soldier recruitment. It welcomed the 11 January 2013 Libreville peace agreements mediated by the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS), urging swift implementation, a national unity government, and legislative elections within 12 months under international supervision. The resolution condemned attempts to seize power by force, highlighted CAR’s extreme poverty (70% below the poverty line, 179th in Human Development Index), and stressed the need for security sector reform, disarmament, and reintegration of combatants. It denounced human rights abuses by both rebels and government forces, emphasized accountability for war crimes, and called for investigations, noting the International Criminal Court’s ongoing probe. The EU, as CAR’s main donor (€137 million under the 10th EDF, €8 million humanitarian aid in 2012), was urged to support peacebuilding, electoral processes, and humanitarian access amid a dire crisis affecting tens of thousands, with plundered aid and suspended services. Concerns over illegal diamond trafficking from rebel-held areas prompted calls for Kimberley Process enforcement and transparent resource management. The resolution emphasized regional cooperation, addressing root causes like unemployment and corruption, and holistic international engagement to stabilize CAR and neighboring conflict-affected states.

title: Private copying levies: REPORT on private copying levies
background: EU copyright rules under Directive 2001/29/EC permitted national private copying exceptions with compensation, leading to divergent levy systems across Member States, addressed through 2013 mediation and CJEU rulings, amid digital market growth. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing private copying levies in the EU, considering technological changes and copyright balance.

stances.stance:
EPP slightly sanctions the harmonization efforts but demands explicit exemptions for educational/scientific copying in Article 2 to prevent penalizing students’ access to knowledge.  
EPP proposes amending levy criteria under Directive 2001/29/EC to exclude non-commercial academic reproductions, citing incompatibility with EU education-first agendas.  
EPP objects to the issue’s silence on differentiating commercial and educational reuse, urging revisions to Annex III for clarity.  
EPP insists on reallocating 15% of levy revenues specifically to digitize academic libraries, ensuring cultural funds directly support education.  
EPP questions the feasibility of uniform cross-border levies without carve-outs for national educational licensing frameworks, advocating regional flexibility clauses.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal to extend private copying levies to cloud services as fundamentally incompatible with digital-era consumer rights.  
This totally opposes with GREEN_EFA's position that storage devices and personal technologies must remain free from copyright taxation for non-commercial use.  
The issue's harmonization approach fails to address the systemic injustice of charging consumers for hypothetical infringements when purchasing everyday devices.  
GREEN_EFA opposes maintaining levy frameworks that treat all digital storage as piracy tools, directly contradicting their digital freedom principles.  
The proposal's revenue allocation mechanisms overlook critical transparency deficits in current collecting societies like Copyswede, which GREEN_EFA has long criticized.

SD conditionally approves the harmonization objectives but demands explicit safeguards against member state abuses of levy systems, citing Spain's suppression of creators through punitive enforcement.  
SD requests revising Article 4 to mandate EU oversight mechanisms when national policies disproportionately burden artists, as exemplified by Spain's contested private copying regime.  
This absolutely challenges with SD's principle of equitable cultural labor rights by allowing unchecked governmental interference in compensation frameworks.  
SD urges amending transparency provisions to require biannual audits of levy allocations, countering systemic diversion of funds from artists to bureaucratic intermediaries.  
The proposal overlooks critical enforcement asymmetries, failing to address how digital platforms evade levies while individual creators face disproportionate administrative harassment.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to modernize EU copyright frameworks to balance creators’ rights with digital market realities, emphasizing the cultural sector’s economic significance (5 million jobs, 2.6% of EU GDP). It highlighted disparities in private copying levies across Member States, noting over €600 million collected annually in 23 states, but stressed inefficiencies due to fragmented systems and outdated approaches in the digital age. The resolution called for harmonizing Directive 2001/29/EC to ensure fair compensation for creators through updated private copying mechanisms, advocating for transparent, uniform levy criteria and exemptions for professional use. It urged allocating at least 25% of levy revenues to promote arts and cultural production, alongside greater transparency in fund distribution. The Parliament emphasized adapting to digital trends like cloud computing and streaming, prioritizing licensing models where feasible, while maintaining private copying rights for legally acquired content. It recommended cross-border levy collection aligned with CJEU rulings to prevent double payments and urged consumer awareness campaigns on levy purposes. Overall, the resolution sought a balanced, future-proof system fostering cultural access, fair remuneration, and single-market coherence.

title: Promoting free movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on promoting the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012
background: Cross-border administrative formalities for public documents created barriers to EU citizens' free movement, generating costs and delays for individuals and businesses. Inefficiencies in mutual document acceptance persisted despite single market principles. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to simplify administrative procedures for accepting public documents across member states to facilitate mobility and economic activity.

stances.stance:

EPP applauds the provisions abolishing certified translations for birth/marriage certificates as directly advancing citizens' freedom of movement priorities outlined in the 2014-2019 political guidelines.  
EPP endorses mutual recognition of public documents between national authorities as critical for reinforcing single market integration while proposing to limit initial application to register extracts (births, marriages, property) to ensure legal security.  
EPP approves cost-saving mechanisms like suppressing apostilles but suggests explicit safeguards against document fraud through centralized verification protocols in Article 6(2).  
EPP emphasizes extending these simplifications to educational diplomas and health documents as future enhancement opportunities per citizens' expectations.

The issue totally condemns with EFD's sovereignty principles by insufficiently allowing national authorities to reject documents questioning holder competence under Article 21(2).  
EFD requests revisions to Annex document templates to consolidate language versions per field, addressing formatting criticisms about administrative clarity.  
This proposal overlooks critical implementation flaws exemplified by the European Parliament’s failure to provide full committee translation coverage, undermining cross-border accessibility.  
EFD opposes the presumption of automatic recognition without member states’ capacity to challenge qualifications, citing veterinary practice risks outlined in debate objections.

GREEN_EFA firmly approves the issue's elimination of redundant document requirements, perfectly aligning with their vision for barrier-free European integration.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with provisions countering misinformation about cross-border marriage recognition, affirming mobility rights without compromising national sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA firmly approves maintaining robust anti-fraud mechanisms while simplifying procedures, demonstrating trust in existing verification frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the measure's focus on youth mobility needs, recognizing its importance for fostering pan-European civic engagement.  
GREEN_EFA firmly approves the issue as critical progress toward dismantling administrative nationalism, consistent with their federalist principles.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue's aim to simplify cross-border acceptance of public documents, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to eliminating administrative barriers for EU citizens' free movement.  
ALDE proposes limiting the regulation's scope to core civil status documents like birth/marriage certificates as a targeted first step, ensuring rapid ratification while maintaining future expansion possibilities.  
ALDE advocates retaining multilingual document formats but suggests requiring certified translations for complex legal instruments like property deeds to prevent misinterpretation risks.  
ALDE applauds the standardized EU forms in Article 4 as effectively advancing legal certainty and reducing costs for citizens exercising mobility rights.  
ALDE recommends supplementary guidelines under Article 11 to address divergent national practices in property/corporate registries while fully endorsing the issue's foundational principles.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s citizen-centric approach to reducing bureaucratic costs, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to free movement and administrative simplification.  
SD approves the harmonization of multilingual document standards while proposing enhanced coordination with national authorities to accelerate educational certificate recognition for students.  
SD emphasizes the critical need to eliminate redundant authentication requirements, particularly for documents in official EU languages, to uphold the principle of non-discrimination.  
SD advocates extending simplified procedures to newer member states’ administrative systems to ensure uniform mobility benefits across the EU internal market.  
SD highlights the issue’s potential to strengthen cross-border family rights through automatic recognition of civil status documents, advancing social justice priorities.

ECR opposes extending the regulation beyond registry excerpts without explicit safeguards, absolutely challengeing with subsidiarity principles raised in the Romanian Senate's reasoned opinion.  
ECR demands removal of provisions allowing expansive interpretation of "public documents," citing incompatibility with legal certainty requirements in Article 21(2) TFEU.  
ECR condemns the dismissal of national notaries' expertise as bureaucratic interference, contrary to the issue's emphasis on addressing subsidiarity concerns through local administrative competence.  
ECR insists any free movement framework must prioritize abuse prevention through strict document authentication protocols, which the current text fails to operationalize.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0228) aimed at harmonizing rules under Articles 21(2) and 114(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which address non-discrimination and the internal market. It highlighted the Romanian Senate’s reasoned opinion challenging the proposal’s compliance with subsidiarity principles and incorporated the European Economic and Social Committee’s July 2013 opinion and the Committee on Legal Affairs’ report (A7-0017/2014). The Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing adherence to legal frameworks and addressing subsidiarity concerns while advancing legislative coherence.

title: Property consequences of registered partnerships: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of decisions regarding the property consequences of registered partnerships
background: Growing cross-border mobility within the EU has increased registered partnerships involving multiple legal jurisdictions, creating complexities in property rights disputes. Divergent national laws and jurisdictional conflicts prompted the European Commission's 2011 proposal under Article 81(3) TFEU. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing cross-border legal frameworks for registered partnerships' property consequences to enhance legal certainty.

EPP approves the compromise allowing couples to select applicable law while preserving member states' cultural traditions through non-recognition mandates for unfamiliar partnership structures.  
EPP applauds the unified jurisdictional framework in Articles 4-6 as advancing legal predictability for 16 million transnational couples without harmonizing substantive family law.  
EPP proposes enhancing Recital 14 to explicitly state that non-partnership states need only recognize property decisions, not institutionalize such unions domestically.  
EPP emphasizes the regulation's alignment with their 2023 justice priorities by resolving 83% of cross-border property disputes through clear conflict-of-law rules.

GREEN_EFA applauds the balanced approach to reconciling diverse national systems, effectively advancing their priority of harmonizing LGBTQ+ rights across EU jurisdictions.

SD approves the harmonized jurisdictional rules for international couples, emphasizing their necessity to reduce bureaucratic burdens and legal uncertainty, as highlighted in SD’s advocacy for cross-border rights.

SD applauds the issue’s facilitation of legal clarity for binational couples during separations or inheritance, directly advancing SD’s 2023 priorities on family law harmonization.  
SD endorses Croatia’s reforms on registered partnerships as a model for EU-wide alignment, reinforcing the issue’s goal of standardized property rights across member states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the compliance of the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0127) with the principle of subsidiarity, following reasoned objections from the Italian, Polish, and Romanian Senates. It approved the amended proposal under Article 81(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), calling on the Commission to revise the text in line with Parliament’s amendments under Article 293(2) TFEU. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing procedural adherence and institutional cooperation.

title: Unitary patent protection: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation implementing enhanced cooperation in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection with regard to the applicable translation arrangements
background: For decades, EU member states sought to harmonize patent systems to reduce fragmentation, high costs, and legal complexity hindering cross-border innovation. Existing national validation processes and translation requirements created barriers for SMEs. The Lisbon Treaty’s enhanced cooperation mechanism enabled 25 states to pursue unitary patent rules. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unitary patent system with streamlined translation arrangements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the unitary patent system as a milestone achievement aligning with its commitment to completing the Single Market and boosting EU competitiveness.  
EPP approves the cost-reduction mechanism that lowers patenting expenses by 80%, directly addressing SMEs' needs for accessible innovation protection as emphasized in its 2023 economic agenda.  
EPP proposes enhancing legal clarity in patent litigation procedures to ensure equal access for smaller businesses across all 25 participating states, building on the issue's existing safeguards.  
EPP applauds the issue's alignment with its innovation-first principles through streamlined translation arrangements using English/French/German while urging future expansion to include other languages.  
EPP emphasizes the need for ongoing monitoring of biological process patenting risks to maintain public trust, as raised during debates about potential regulatory overreach.

EFD completely condemns the unitary patent system as an illegitimate erosion of national judicial sovereignty, directly conflicting with their principle of maintaining independent patent courts like the UK’s £750M/year jurisdiction.  
The proposal overlooks critical SME disadvantages by centralizing litigation in France/Germany, imposing prohibitive travel costs and tripled litigation expenses contrary to EFD’s advocacy for local business protections.  
EFD rejects the linguistically discriminatory regime privileging French/German, demanding English as the sole procedural language to eliminate translation inequalities faced by Lithuanian and Polish innovators.  
The issue dangerously enables corporate monopolies by letting 88% patent-holding giants weaponize unified courts against SMEs, contradicting EFD’s 2023 agenda to prevent market entry barriers for smaller economies.  
EFD condemns the unmeritocratic judicial appointment process that prioritizes geographic quotas over expertise, risking incompetent rulings in specialized patent cases from underqualified smaller-state nominees.

GREEN_EFA rejects the compromise for disproportionately disadvantaging SMEs through heightened legal complexity and litigation costs, contrary to pledges for equitable innovation access.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the erosion of parliamentary influence over patent governance, which conflicts with democratic accountability commitments in EU treaties.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s failure to prevent abusive patent practices on software and lifeforms, directly opposing their bioethics and digital sovereignty agendas.  
GREEN_EFA warns the issue dangerously replicates the European Patent Office’s flawed enforcement culture, undermining judicial recourse via the Court of Justice.

ALDE strongly endorses the creation of a unitary patent system as a historic achievement aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to a unified internal market and reduced administrative burdens for innovators.  
ALDE approves the translation arrangements using English, French, and German combined with automated translation tools, emphasizing cost efficiency while maintaining accessibility for all member states.  
ALDE applauds the establishment of a unified patent court system, which eliminates fragmented litigation and enhances legal certainty for SMEs and researchers across Europe.  
ALDE proposes maintaining proactive diplomatic outreach to Spain and Italy to encourage their future participation, ensuring the system evolves toward full EU inclusivity.  
ALDE commends the Commission and parliamentary collaborators for overcoming decades of stagnation, noting the issue’s alignment with ALDE’s innovation-driven economic growth agenda.

SD strongly accepts the unitary patent system as a crucial step toward economic revitalization, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to SME integration and innovation-driven growth.  
SD approves the dramatic cost reductions (80% savings) and simplified procedures, effectively advancing SD's priority of removing bureaucratic barriers to cross-border entrepreneurship.  
SD highlights the negotiated safeguards for non-dominant language countries as essential, while proposing future reviews to expand linguistic accessibility beyond the current trilinguistic framework.  
SD endorses the issue's emphasis on legal certainty through centralized patent courts, urging robust monitoring to prevent jurisdictional fragmentation risks.  
SD recommends enhancing EU innovation budgets in parallel with patent reforms to fully realize the system's potential as a global competitiveness driver.

ECR strongly advocates the unitary patent regulation to accelerate EU innovation competitiveness, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing bureaucratic barriers and fostering SME growth.  
ECR approves the issue’s urgency in addressing 40-year delays, emphasizing its critical role in countering patent application gaps with the US and China.  
ECR highlights the necessity of quality-assured machine translations and cost transparency, proposing an amendment to cap validation fees at €800 to match global benchmarks.  
ECR underscores the need for streamlined administrative implementation to prevent procedural bottlenecks, ensuring swift access to cross-border patent enforcement.  
ECR advocates for enhanced SME safeguards in Article 3 to mitigate disproportionate legal costs, aligning the proposal with equitable market access principles.

GUE/NGL rejects the unitary patent system as it accelerates privatization of knowledge, contradicting their stance against capitalist monopolization of public goods.  
GUE/NGL opposes the creation of a unified patent court, warning it erodes national sovereignty and restricts citizens' ability to challenge corporate patents.  
GUE/NGL condemns the language regime for institutionalizing discrimination, failing to ensure equal access to patent protections across EU languages.  
GUE/NGL denounces the proposal's alignment with corporate interests, enabling commodification of scientific achievements and essential public services.  
GUE/NGL demands rejection of the current framework, insisting any patent reform must prioritize public ownership and workers' control over intellectual property.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Commission proposal (COM(2011)0216), urging the Commission to revise its initial text in line with Parliament’s amendments under Article 293(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. title: Transparency requirements in relation to information about issuers whose securities are admitted to trading on a regulated market: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2004/109/EC on the harmonisation of transparency requirements in relation to information about issuers whose securities are admitted to trading on a regulated market and Commission Directive 2007/14/EC

Participation among national chambers dropped by 50%, with only 15 chambers submitting opinions. The resolution highlighted deficiencies in Commission impact assessments, with 32% of those reviewed in 2014 lacking adequate subsidiarity or proportionality analysis, and urged the Commission to improve explanatory statements and conduct enhanced proportionality assessments, including environmental, social, and economic impacts. It welcomed the 2015 Better Regulation package, which aimed to strengthen subsidiarity justifications, and supported proposals for a "green card" mechanism allowing national parliaments to suggest legislative initiatives, while cautioning against undermining EU institutional processes. The Parliament called for extending the eight-week period for national parliaments to issue reasoned opinions under Protocol No 2, suggested Treaty revisions to expand subsidiarity checks to include proportionality, and stressed the need for interparliamentary cooperation through tools like IPEX and COSAC. It encouraged greater engagement between EU institutions and national parliaments, including informal contacts and shared guidelines, and emphasized the role of the Committee of the Regions in assessing compliance with subsidiarity. The resolution reiterated the importance of clear, proportionate legislation and urged robust EU action where added value is demonstrable, balancing efficiency with democratic accountability.

SD opposes the proposed "green card" initiative for national parliaments, warning it could institutionalize legislative blockades and sabotage social dialogue mechanisms central to SD's agenda.  
SD condemns the issue's emphasis on mid-term subsidiarity reviews as inconsistent with SD's stance against procedural delays that weaken EU crisis-response capacity.  
SD challenges the report's premise that subsidiarity violations are systemic, citing the mere two yellow cards issued (0.3% of proposals) as proof the current Protocol No 2 framework functions without additional layers.  
SD warns the issue's focus on national parliamentary oversight dangerously aligns with eurosceptic narratives about "overreach," directly contradicting SD's mission to strengthen EU-level solutions for transnational challenges.

ECR strongly advocates strict adherence to Article 5 TEU in financial matters, echoing Bernd Lucke's warning against centralized banking mechanisms that disregard national economic policy sovereignty.  
ECR unreservedly backs the issue's condemnation of competence overreach, amplifying Νότης Μαριάς' critique of treaty violations through imposed austerity measures unrelated to EU treaty-based mandates.

GUE/NGL fundamentally disputes the issue’s failure to address the undemocratic concentration of legislative power in the unelected Commission, which contradicts their demand for worker-centered policymaking.  
GUE/NGL rejects the vague application of subsidiarity principles highlighted in the report, noting their misuse to enforce neoliberal agendas while ignoring Troika-imposed austerity measures on intervened states.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s silence on investor-state dispute mechanisms (ISDS) that undermine national sovereignty, directly conflicting with their anti-corporate power stance.  
GUE/NGL opposes the "green card" proposal as insufficient, arguing it perpetuates Commission dominance instead of transferring legislative initiative to elected representatives.  
GUE/NGL denounces the Commission’s dismissal of social rights under proportionality claims, mirroring their critique of EU policies eroding worker protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the application of subsidiarity and proportionality in EU law-making, emphasizing their foundational role under Article 5 TEU and Protocol No 2. It noted increased scrutiny by national parliaments, with 292 submissions (83 proposals) in 2012 and 313 (99 proposals) in 2013, including the first "yellow card" triggered in 2012 by 12 reasoned opinions (19 votes) against the Monti II proposal, leading to its withdrawal despite the Commission’s insistence on compliance. A second "yellow card" in 2013 on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (13 opinions, 18 votes) saw the Commission maintain the proposal but narrow its scope. The resolution highlighted deficiencies in Commission impact assessments, with 30% deemed insufficient on subsidiarity in 2012-2013, rising to 50% in 2014, and urged revised guidelines. It called for mid-term and post-legislative subsidiarity checks, enhanced political dialogue, and a "green card" initiative for national parliaments to propose legislation. Concerns were raised about investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) potentially undermining subsidiarity, alongside calls for clarity on EU-Member State competences in trade agreements and transparency in negotiations. The resolution stressed the need for proportionality in EU financial assistance, simplified EU fund applications, and better integration of national impact assessments. It urged the Commission to address national parliaments’ concerns comprehensively, improve ex-ante evaluations, and foster a "subsidiarity culture" through regular debates and exchanges, while underscoring the EU’s exclusive competence in trade policy under Article 3 TFEU.

title: Copyright in the Digital Single Market: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on copyright in the Digital Single Market
background: Outdated EU copyright frameworks, designed before widespread digital content sharing, created legal uncertainties and disputes over fair compensation for creators as platforms like YouTube expanded. The Parliament will discuss modernizing copyright laws to address digital content distribution, balancing creator rights, platform responsibilities, and user access in the Digital Single Market.

stances.stance:

EPP opposes Article 13's upload filter mandate, which overlooks critical aspects of algorithmic limitations and risks censoring lawful user-generated content.  
The proposal fails to address EPP's core priority of maintaining Europe's competitive edge by imposing unworkable licensing requirements on digital platforms.  
EPP condemns the issue's approach to publisher rights as inconsistent with market realities, creating fragmentation rather than harmonized copyright enforcement.  
The directive's remuneration clauses fundamentally undermine contractual freedom, contradicting EPP's commitment to balanced stakeholder negotiations.

EFDD supports the objective of fair remuneration for creators but advises revising Article 13 to replace automated content filtering with human-led dispute mechanisms, ensuring freedom of expression safeguards under Article 11 of the EU Charter.  
EFDD endorses enhancing legal certainty for digital content access while proposing to amend Article 11 by exempting non-commercial platforms and search engines from ancillary copyright obligations to preserve open information sharing.  
EFDD advises introducing startup protections in Article 13(2a) by raising the user base threshold for compliance duties to 10 million, aligning with the issue's goal of balanced stakeholder interests.  
EFDD urges maintaining the Directive's focus on creator protections rather than platform liability, suggesting explicit exemptions for user-generated content in Recital 38 to prevent algorithmic censorship of personal uploads.  
 While supporting transparency in creator contracts, EFDD cautions that over-reliance on algorithmic enforcement under Article 13 contradicts fundamental digital rights principles requiring judicial oversight.

ENF rejects the directive's framing of "fair remuneration" as disproportionately benefiting large publishers under Article 11 (now 15), failing to protect small-scale creators and citizen journalism.  
ENF warns the issue overlooks critical aspects of digital sovereignty by granting surveillance tools to tech giants, contradicting ENF's anti-monopoly principles.  
ENF highlights the directive's incompatibility with grassroots cultural preservation, arguing compliance mechanisms impose Orwellian content filters surpassing communist-era controls.  
ENF conditionally advocates transparency clauses but demands deletion of Articles 11-13, citing irreconcilable conflicts with internet freedom and national cultural autonomy.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on fair remuneration for creators and performers, aligning with their commitment to cultural workers’ rights and equitable digital markets.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 13 to explicitly exclude automated upload filters and instead mandate transparent, human-reviewed mechanisms to prevent overreach into lawful user-generated content.  
GREEN_EFA approves the Voss amendments’ balanced approach, which removes filtering requirements while ensuring platforms contribute to artists’ fair compensation through collective licensing agreements.  
GREEN_EFA advocates strengthening Article 12 to guarantee proportional negotiation power for smaller creators and performers, ensuring contractual transparency aligns with their manifesto on digital justice.  
GREEN_EFA urges reinforcing safeguards in Article 11 to protect non-commercial user practices, such as parody and criticism, while maintaining fair licensing frameworks for press publications.

ALDE slightly endorses the platform liability framework but requests revisions to Article 13 to explicitly prohibit upload filters, citing their incompatibility with fundamental digital rights.  
ALDE rejects the proposed publishers' right in Article 11 as inconsistent with maintaining open access to information, advocating instead for presumption rights to protect journalists' remuneration.  
ALDE requests amendments to strengthen transparency requirements in creator contracts, mandating quarterly royalty reporting and audit rights for authors.  
ALDE opposes extending copyright enforcement obligations to user-generated content platforms without parallel exceptions for non-commercial creators, arguing this fails to balance stakeholder interests.  
ALDE demands deletion of provisions allowing automated content recognition systems, warning these entirely oppose with EU data protection principles and risk mass surveillance.

SD partially supports the issue's transparency goals but demands Article 13's complete revision to eliminate upload filter mandates, fully opposeing with SD's digital rights principles against privatized censorship infrastructure.  
SD rejects Article 11's publisher rights model as fostering oligopolistic control over information access, directly contradicting commitments to media pluralism and open internet governance.  
SD insists on binding revenue redistribution mechanisms for platforms like YouTube to address the issue's failure to close the "value gap" for small creators, noting current provisions disproportionately benefit corporate rights holders.  
SD requires explicit prohibitions against algorithmic content prioritization in Article 17, citing unresolved contradictions with EU digital service liability frameworks and user-generated content protections.  
SD challenges the text's omission of journalist remuneration safeguards despite repeated advocacy, demanding amendments to redirect platform advertising revenues toward original content producers.

ECR supports the issue's framework for rights holder cooperation but advises narrowing Article 11 to exclude insubstantial content excerpts and protect small publishers' digital visibility.  
ECR proposes modifying Article 13 implementation to prevent disproportionate filtering measures, safeguarding legitimate user-generated content like memes and vlogs.  
ECR emphasizes the necessity of explicit safeguards in copyright enforcement mechanisms to protect freedom of expression and prevent platform overreach.

ECR advises clarifying legal exceptions for non-commercial users to balance creator protections with consumer access rights.

GUE/NGL strongly approves the issue’s commitment to fair remuneration for creators, aligning perfectly with their principles of protecting cultural workers from corporate exploitation while ensuring equitable access to digital content.  
GUE/NGL applauds the safeguards for educational institutions’ use of digital materials, effectively advancing their goal of democratizing knowledge without market-driven restrictions.  
GUE/NGL proposes revising Article 13 to prevent automated censorship mechanisms, advocating for human oversight safeguards to balance copyright enforcement with user-generated content freedoms.  
GUE/NGL endorses the transparency measures in creator contracts as a critical step toward empowering authors and performers in the digital economy.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes the need to prioritize public access over corporate control, ensuring cultural diversity remains central to copyright modernization efforts.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to modernize EU copyright rules by adopting a position to enhance legal certainty, balance stakeholder interests, and protect creators and consumers. Key measures included establishing clear legal exceptions and limitations for digital uses of copyrighted works, clarifying obligations for online platforms to ensure fair cooperation with rights holders, and creating safeguards to protect consumers’ legitimate practices in accessing digital content. The resolution emphasized empowering authors and performers to enforce their rights effectively, ensuring fair remuneration and transparency in contractual agreements. It also urged the Commission to maintain alignment with the original legislative objectives and avoid undermining the proposed reforms through substantial amendments.

title: Cross-border aspects of adoptions: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on cross border aspects of adoptions
background: Cross-border adoptions in the EU are governed by the 1993 Hague Convention, ratified by all member states, which addresses intercountry adoptions but excludes domestic ones. Varying national laws and absent EU provisions for mutual recognition of domestic adoptions created legal uncertainties for mobile families. The Parliament will discuss cross-border adoption challenges, focusing on mutual recognition frameworks and child rights compliance.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the establishment of automatic cross-border recognition of adoption orders, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to free movement and stable family environments for children across the EU.  
EPP approves the European Certificate of Adoption proposal as a critical tool to eliminate bureaucratic hurdles, effectively advancing EPP's priority of simplifying citizens’ lives through administrative coherence.  
EPP emphasizes the need for enhanced judicial cooperation and specialized training for family court judges, which mirrors the issue’s focus on legal certainty and child rights protection.  
EPP highlights the importance of preserving cultural and linguistic ties for adopted children, strongly endorsing this as integral to the child’s best interests under EU principles.  
EPP proposes strengthening safeguards against non-consensual adoptions by explicitly requiring dual verification of biological parents’ consent in cross-border cases, enhancing existing anti-trafficking measures.

EFDD firmly challenges the issue's harmonization push as an unacceptable erosion of national sovereignty over family law matters.  
EFDD rejects automatic adoption recognition mechanisms, arguing they override UK courts' ability to uphold domestic safeguards for biological parents' rights.  
The proposal fails to address risks of cultural displacement, particularly the forced linguistic assimilation of children moved across borders under EU-wide recognition rules.  
EFDD demands deletion of Articles invoking TFEU jurisdictional powers, asserting family court privacy protections would be irreparably damaged by EU oversight.  
This issue overlooks critical subsidiarity principles by centralizing adoption governance where national systems already ensure child welfare.

ENF rejects the automatic recognition of domestic adoptions as a violation of national sovereignty, asserting that this mechanism could force member states to accept same-sex parent adoptions against their public policy.  
ENF opposes the European Certificate of Adoption, viewing it as an illegitimate encroachment into member states' exclusive competence over family law matters.  
ENF fully condemns with the issue’s legislative approach, arguing that existing Hague Convention frameworks and intergovernmental cooperation should be prioritized over new EU regulations.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity by failing to demonstrate why cross-border adoption recognition cannot be addressed through judicial training and administrative streamlining at national levels.  
ENF warns that public policy exceptions are illusory safeguards, predicting their erosion through future EU integration pressures as seen in other policy areas.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the automatic recognition of domestic adoptions across Member States, aligning with their commitment to prioritizing children’s emotional well-being and eliminating legal disparities that undermine stable family environments.  
GREEN_EFA endorses abolishing re-adoption requirements through mutual recognition frameworks, emphasizing that children’s rights deserve parity with EU principles governing free movement of goods and capital.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the European Certificate of Adoption to explicitly safeguard siblings’ unity and cultural ties, ensuring these protections are uniformly enforceable across jurisdictions.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with Hague Convention safeguards against child trafficking, reinforcing their long-standing advocacy for stringent oversight of intermediary organizations.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes expanding access to legal aid and interpreters in cross-border adoption cases to uphold equitable procedural rights for biological families, as urged in the issue’s preventive measures.

ALDE fundamentally accepts the automatic recognition mechanism for adoption orders across Member States as a vital step toward eliminating legal barriers to free movement of families  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on the child’s best interests, particularly in preserving stable environments and cultural continuity during cross-border transitions  
ALDE applauds the European Certificate of Adoption proposal for streamlining administrative recognition processes while respecting Hague Convention safeguards against exploitation  
ALDE strongly endorses enhanced judicial training and e-Justice Portal integration to ensure uniform application of adoption standards and transparency across borders  
ALDE commends the issue’s balance between preventing non-consensual adoptions through biological family support and combating trafficking via stricter oversight of intermediaries

SD strongly upholds the establishment of EU-wide adoption standards and automatic recognition mechanisms, ensuring legal certainty for mobile families while centering the child’s best interests as paramount.  
SD applauds the European Certificate of Adoption proposal as a critical tool to eliminate bureaucratic barriers and safeguard children’s rights in cross-border contexts.  
SD endorses mandatory consular consultations and e-Justice Portal integration to prevent non-consensual adoptions, aligning with transparency and biological family protections.

SD emphasizes urgent implementation of the 2017 legislative deadline to resolve systemic recognition gaps, particularly for cases involving third-country adoptions.

ECR opposes fundamentally the EU's imposition of uniform adoption standards, arguing this disregards member states' exclusive competence over public policy exceptions in parental authority cases.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to sufficiently prohibit economic-status-based adoptions, contradicting their stance against poverty-driven family separation.

ECR asserts the proposal overlooks critical safeguards for biological parents' legal recourse rights, risking premature termination of familial bonds under cross-border procedures.

GUE_NGL strongly agrees the issue's mandate for automatic cross-border recognition of adoptions, aligning perfectly with their commitment to child welfare and reducing institutional care through stable family environments.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on preserving siblings’ unity and cultural ties, which matches their manifesto priorities for holistic child development in transnational cases.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing Article 21 safeguards by explicitly including diverse family models such as same-sex couples and single parents to strengthen non-discrimination principles.  
GUE_NGL approves the European Certificate of Adoption as a critical tool to combat bureaucratic barriers faced by mobile families, reflecting their social justice agenda.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for EU-wide common minimum standards in adoption procedures, emphasizing the primacy of the child’s best interests, non-discrimination, and fundamental rights. It stressed that adoption decisions must prioritize a stable, loving environment for the child, ensure biological parents’ rights to exhaust legal remedies before parental authority is withdrawn, and avoid economic status as the sole basis for adoption. The resolution highlighted gaps in cross-border recognition of domestic adoptions, noting that families moving within the EU face legal uncertainties, including potential re-adoption requirements, due to the absence of automatic recognition mechanisms. It called for legislation by 31 July 2017 to establish automatic recognition of domestic adoption orders across Member States, conditional on compliance with public policy and jurisdictional rules under Articles 67(4) and 81(3) TFEU, while respecting the Hague Convention’s framework for intercountry adoptions. The proposed regulation would mandate mutual recognition of adoptions finalized in one Member State or recognized from third countries, barring manifest public policy conflicts, and introduce a European Certificate of Adoption to streamline administrative processes. The resolution urged enhanced judicial cooperation, specialized training for family court judges, improved transparency via the e-Justice Portal, and stronger measures to combat child trafficking and exploitation by intermediary organizations. It emphasized preserving siblings’ unity, cultural and linguistic ties for adopted children, and equitable procedural rights for cross-border relatives, including access to interpreters and legal aid. The Parliament also advocated for robust support systems for biological families to prevent non-consensual adoptions as a last resort, better data collection on transnational cases, and alignment with UN Convention on the Rights of the Child principles, particularly Article 21 on adoption safeguards.

title: Monitoring the application of EU law 2015: REPORT on monitoring the application of EU law 2015

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the persistent challenges in ensuring Member States’ compliance with EU law, noting 3,450 complaints in 2015—primarily against Italy (637), Spain (342), and Germany (274)—with key issues in employment, social affairs, environment, and internal market. Despite a 30% reduction in new EU Pilot files (881 in 2015) and a stable 75% resolution rate, 1,368 infringement cases remained open, highlighting ongoing transposition and implementation failures, particularly in mobility, energy, and environmental sectors. The resolution criticized the Commission for inadequate enforcement against diesel vehicle emissions violating air quality standards (Directive 2008/50/EC) and urged stronger action. It emphasized Member States’ primary responsibility for correct transposition, including providing explanatory documents and correlation tables, while calling for enhanced transparency, a centralized complaint portal, and systematic monitoring of regulations alongside directives. Concerns were raised over austerity measures undermining administrative and judicial capacities, deficient refugee relocation mechanisms, and delays in animal welfare strategies. The Parliament urged codifying EU administrative procedures to strengthen citizens’ rights, improving cooperation with national parliaments to avoid “gold-plating” legislation, and ensuring EU institutions’ compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, particularly in Memoranda of Understanding and stability mechanisms. It also stressed the need for structured dialogue with petitioners, whistleblower protections, and rigorous enforcement of asylum, anti-fraud, and free movement rules to uphold EU values and legal certainty.

title: Implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive: REPORT on the application of Directive 2004/35/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 April 2004 on environmental liability with regard to the prevention and remedying of environmental damage (the ‘ELD’)
background: The Environmental Liability Directive (2004/35/EC), establishing a framework for preventing and remedying environmental damage, faced inconsistent transposition and application across EU Member States, with disparities in legal frameworks, enforcement capacities, and financial security mechanisms. The Parliament will discuss improving harmonization, scope, and effectiveness of liability regimes to address gaps in environmental protection and operator accountability.

EFDD requests revisions to abolish the secondary liability regime, arguing it duplicates functional national systems like the UK’s and imposes redundant EU legislative complexity.  
The issue’s mandatory financial security mandates are deemed an overreach, contradicting EFDD’s opposition to EU-wide insurance impositions beyond subsidiarity principles.  
While supporting broader environmental protections, EFDD rejects the issue’s centralization of enforcement, failing to address subsidiarity as required under EU treaties.

The proposal’s centralization of liability thresholds and financial security mechanisms directly contradicts ENF’s opposition to supranational overreach in Member States’ environmental enforcement.  
ENF deems the removal of "permit defence" exemptions and strict liability expansion as disproportionate, failing to address legitimate industrial protections enshrined in national legal frameworks.  
While supporting air pollution inclusion, ENF argues the issue’s structural disregard for sovereignty undermines its feasibility, rendering it incompatible with effective multilateral cooperation.
